case_vignette:
A 15-year-old girl presents with patches of hair loss on her scalp that have been present for the last 6 months. She reports that her scalp is not itchy or painful and denies any recent illnesses, diet changes, or stressful life events. She does not have any other medical conditions and takes no medications. Her uncle had a similar condition that started when he was in his 20s, but no one else in the family has experienced hair loss. The patient says she has not tried any treatments for the condition. On examination, she has several well-demarcated patches of hair loss on her frontal and parietal scalp, with no perifollicular erythema or scale. The patient's hair loss is consistent with alopecia areata, a condition characterized by patchy hair loss due to an autoimmune response.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have patches of hair loss on my scalp that have been there for the last 6 months.
Have you noticed any scaling or redness in the areas where you are experiencing hair loss?
No, there is no redness or scaling in the areas of hair loss.
Are the patches of hair loss smooth and completely bald, or do you see any broken hairs?
The patches of hair loss are smooth and completely bald.
Do you have a personal or family history of autoimmune diseases?
My uncle had a similar condition that started when he was in his 20s, but no one else in the family has experienced hair loss.
Do you have any other symptoms like itching, pain, or changes in the texture of your nails?
No, my scalp is not itchy or painful, and I have not noticed any changes in the texture of my nails.
Final Diagnosis: Alopecia Areata.
